CHAPTER 90: ALARM SYSTEMS
Section
   
90.01   Installation in Police Department approved
   
90.02   Definitions
   
90.03   License required to engage in alarm business
   
90.04   Employees must be licensed with the Police Department
   
90.05   Property owner needs permit for installation of alarm system
   
90.06   Alarms connected to telephones prohibited
   
90.07   Licenses and permits
   
90.08   False alarms
   
90.09   Filing of rates and charges
   
90.99   Penalty
§ 90.01 INSTALLATION IN POLICE DEPARTMENT APPROVED.
   The installation in the Police Department of components of burglary and
other emergency alarm systems serving residences and other buildings in the
village is approved and authorized subject to the terms and conditions of this
chapter.
('80 Code, § 95.01) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)
§ 90.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall have
the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.
   ALARM AGENT.
      (1)   Any person who is employed by an alarm business, either directly or
indirectly, whose duties include any of the following: selling, maintaining,
leasing, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, or installing on or
in any building, structure, or facility, any alarm system.
      (2)   EXEMPTION. The provisions of this section do not include a person
who engages in the manufacture or sale of an alarm system from a fixed location
and who neither visits the location where the alarm system is to be installed,
nor designs the scheme for physical location and installation of the alarm
system in a specific location.
   ALARM BUSINESS. The business by any individual, partnership, corporation, or
other entity of: selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering,
replacing, moving, or installing any alarm system in residences and other
structures.
   ALARM SYSTEM. Any mechanical, radio, or electrical device which is designed
or used for the detection of an unauthorized entry into and/or for the
detection of fire or other emergency situation within a building, or for
alerting others of the commission of an unlawful act within a building or both;
and which emits a sound or transmits a signal when activated.
   FALSE ALARM. An alarm signal necessitating response by the Police Department
where an emergency situation does not exist.
   LICENSEE. Any person, firm, partnership, association, or corporation who, or
which, shall be granted a license as provided herein, and his or its employees,
agents, and representatives.
   PROPRIETOR ALARM. An alarm which is not serviced by an alarm business.
   PERMITTEE. One who holds a valid permit as herein provided.
('80 Code, § 95.02) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)
§ 90.03 LICENSE REQUIRED TO ENGAGE IN ALARM BUSINESS.
   It shall be unlawful for any individual or business entity to engage in the
alarm business in residences within the corporate limits of the village without
first obtaining a license at the police department.
('80 Code, § 95.03) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)
Penalty, see § 90.99
§ 90.04 EMPLOYEES MUST BE LICENSED WITH THE POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   It shall be unlawful for any individual or business entity to engage in the
alarm business in the village through the use of any employee not previously
licensed with the Police Department in accordance with §
90.07.
('80 Code, § 95.04) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)
Penalty, see § 90.99
§ 90.05 PROPERTY OWNER NEEDS PERMIT FOR INSTALLATION OF ALARM SYSTEM.
   No burglary or other emergency alarm system shall be installed in any
residence or other building in this village until a permit for the installation
is issued to the property owner.
('80 Code, § 95.05) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)
Penalty, see § 90.99
§ 90.06 ALARMS CONNECTED TO TELEPHONES PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall use or cause to be used any alarm
system which automatically selects or dials a telephone or telephone trunk line
used by or assigned to the village for telephone service, which system then
transmits over the line a report or alarm concerning a burglary, fire, or other
police emergency, except that any installed prior to April 25, 1977 will not be
affected, and that licenses shall be issued to such person, firm, partnership,
association, or corporation, limited to those alarms installed as of that date.
('80 Code, § 95.06) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)
Penalty, see § 90.99
§ 90.07 LICENSES AND PERMITS.
   (A)   Licenses.
      (1)   Alarm business license. No person shall engage in, conduct, or
carry on an alarm business without first applying for and receiving an alarm
business license therefor in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
      (2)   Alarm agent license. No person shall engage in, conduct, or operate
as an alarm agent without first applying for and receiving an alarm agent
license therefor in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
      (3)   In addition, the following information will also be required:
         (a)   Name and address of applicant.
         (b)   Full local address of applicant.
         (c)   The name, address, and other necessary pertinent information of
all alarm agents sought to be used in connection with any installation made in
the village.
   (B)   The Police Chief may dispense with the investigation upon being
furnished with an authenticated copy of a current license issued by another
governmental agency located in the county. The permit shall be denied by the
Police Chief if:
      (1)   The character or reputation of the applicant is determined to be
inimical to the safety or general welfare of the community; or
      (2)   The applicant, his employee, or agent has knowingly made false,
misleading, or fraudulent statements of a material fact in the application for
a license; or
      (3)   The applicant has had a similar type license previously revoked for
a good cause.
   (C)   Alarm system permit. No person shall possess or use an alarm system
without first applying for and receiving an alarm permit therefor in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter. In addition, the following information
will also be requested:
      (1)   Name and address of property owner.
      (2)   The location of all alarmed doors, windows, pressure pads, or other
devices which would trigger the alarm.
      (3)   The location of all alarm consoles and operational instructions for
each alarm location.
      (4)   The name of the company installing the system.
      (5)   An agreement to deposit a key to the protected building and a key
to the alarm system used in the residence or protected building, and to provide
access to the main control panel.
      (6)   Agreement to use an assigned code number of the installation.
   (D)   The record in division (C) shall be privileged and not available for
public inspection. No employee of the village shall divulge any information
obtained in connection with the permit application.
('80 Code, § 95.07) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)
Penalty, see § 90.99
§ 90.08 FALSE ALARMS.
   (A)   The Chief of Police shall keep an accurate record of all false alarms.
   (B)   An alarm system shall constitute a public nuisance if it activates
more than three false alarms in any 360-day period. Each false alarm record
will be eliminated on the 360th day after that false alarm.
   (C)   When the holder of a permit for an alarm system activates more than
three false alarms in a 360 day period, a $15 responding fee shall be charged
to that holder for each of the fourth and fifth false alarms.
   (D)   For the sixth false alarm in a 360- day period a $30 responding fee
shall be charged to the holder.
   (E)   The seventh false alarm of the alarm of a holder in a 360-day period
constitutes an offense and will result in the issuance of a citation to Mayor's
Court.
   (F)   Subscribers shall keep their alarm system in good repair.
   (G)   Subscribers and permittees shall notify the Police Department prior to
any service, test, repair, maintenance, adjustment, alteration, or installation
which might activate a false alarm.
   (H)   Each false alarm in excess of three in any 360-day period shall
constitute a separate responding fee.
      (1)   For the first false alarm within a 360-day period, the Police
Department will advise the permittee in writing that the false alarm has
occurred and recommend that appropriate steps be taken to prevent future
occurrences.
      (2)   Upon the occurrence of a second false alarm within a 360-day
period, the Police Department will send a second written communication to the
permittee advising of the false alarm and of the consequence of continued false
alarms.
      (3)   Upon the occurrence of the third false alarm in a 360-day period,
the Police Department will cause a Police Officer to contact the permittee to
attempt to correct the situation and to advise the permittee that a fourth
false alarm within a 360-day period will result in a fee being imposed.
      (4)   Upon the occurrence of the fourth, fifth and sixth false alarms,
the Police Department will serve the permittee an invoice for the responding
fee specified in divisions (C) or (D) of this section.
      (5)   Upon the occurrence of the seventh false alarm, the Police
Department shall issue a citation to the permittee as specified in division (E)
of this section.
   (I)   The first false alarm of an alarm system for which there is no valid
permit outstanding shall constitute a responding fee being levied as prescribed
in division (C) of this section.
('80 Code, § 95.08) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77; Am. Ord. 14-89, passed 6-19-
89)
Penalty, see § 90.99
§ 90.09 FILING OF RATES AND CHARGES.
   Beginning on August 1, 1980, and thereafter, no alarm business shall conduct
its business within the village without having filed with the City Manager a
schedule of rates and charges. The alarm business license, as provided for in §
90.07 hereof, of any such alarm business failing to file a schedule of rates
and charges on or before August 1, 1980 shall be revoked. All applicants for
alarm business license shall file with the Manager a schedule of rates and
charges for its services before any alarm business license shall be issued. At
any time there is to be a change in rates and charges of an alarm business for
services provided within the village, the alarm business shall file a new
schedule of rates and charges reflecting such changes to be effective on 30
days notice. No alarm business engaging in that business in the village from
and after August 1, 1980 shall charge for the services it provides other than
those rates and charges which are on file with the Manager. So long as any
alarm business utilizes the premises of the Indian Hill Rangers, the City
Manager, or Council may, from time to time, require such supporting data and
information as he shall determine is appropriate to demonstrate the
reasonableness of all rates and charges to be filed by an alarm business with
rates and charges on file.
('80 Code, § 95.09) (Ord. 12-80, passed 6-23-80)
Penalty, see § 90.99
§ 90.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined not more than $50 for each offense. A person so
fined may pay the $50 within 168 hours of the date of the citation without
court appearance or may appear in court at the time and place indicated in the
citation.
('80 Code, § 95.99) (Am. Ord. 14-89, passed 6-19- 89)

   DOGS AND CATS
§ 91.01 MALICIOUS ACTIVITY OF DOG OR CAT PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any owner or harborer of any dog or cat to suffer
the dog or cat to injure, chase, or put in fear of physical harm any person, or
damage any person's gardens, lawns, shrubbery, or other and different property.
Strict liability is intended to be imposed for a violation of this section.
('80 Code, § 90.01) (Ord. 20-78, passed 10-30-78; Am. Ord. 10-99, passed 6-21-
99) Penalty, see § 91.99(A)
§ 91.02 COMPLAINTS FILED IN WRITING WITH CITY MANAGER.
   (A)   Any person who has been injured, attacked physically, chased, or put
in fear of physical harm, or whose gardens, lawns, shrubbery, or other and
different property has been extensively, irreparably, or repeatedly injured or
damaged by a dog or cat, may register in writing a complaint thereof with the
Police Department. An adult may file such a complaint on behalf of a minor
child in his care or custody. The complaint shall be in the form of a sworn
affidavit and shall specify the incident complained of, the date of occurrence,
a description of the dog or cat, the name and address of the owner or harborer
of the dog or cat, and such other information as may reasonably be required to
describe the offense complained of, and shall be signed by the person making
the complaint. A form of the complaint may be prepared by the Police
Department. A member of the Indian Hill Rangers shall sign and issue a summons,
which shall be served in person to the alleged owner or harborer.
   (B)   Once a complaint is filed, as provided herein, the Rangers shall, when
serving a copy of the complaint upon the owner or harborer, also serve a notice
that the animal or animals identified in the complaint be restricted in the
same manner as provided in §
91.05. Once the notice is served, the owner or harborer shall restrict the
animal in the same manner as provided in §
91.05 until the complaint is disposed by Mayor's Court. Each occasion that an
owner or harborer fails to restrict an animal as provided herein shall
constitute a separate offense. Where the owner or harborer of an animal which
has been restricted in accordance with this subsection or §
91.04 owns or harbors more than one animal subject to this chapter, each
subsequent occasion that the owner or harborer fails to restrict such animal,
whether or not it is the same animal previously restricted, shall be a separate
offense. An owner or harborer failing to restrict their animals as provided
herein shall be subject to the penalties provided in §
91.99.
('80 Code, § 91.02) (Ord. 20-78, passed 10-30-78; Am. Ord. 32-78, passed 12-18-
78; Am. Ord. 20-81, passed 11-23-81; Am. Ord. 7-86, passed 4-21-86; Am. Ord.
16-95, passed 9-25-95; Am. Ord. 09-00, passed 5-22-00)
§ 91.03 RESPONSIBILITY OF HARBORER.
   Any person who shall allow any dog or cat habitually to remain or be lodged
and be fed within his home or other building on his property shall be
considered as harboring that dog or cat, and shall be responsible therefor.
('80 Code, § 90.03) (Ord. 20-78, passed 10-30-78)
§ 91.04 NOTICE; HEARING RESTRICTION.
   The owner or harborer so notified shall be afforded an opportunity to appear
before the Mayor's Court, at which time the Court shall determine whether the
subject dog or cat did, in fact, commit the offensive acts alleged. The owner
or harborer of the dog or cat shall be entitled to be present in person or by
counsel, to present evidence and to cross-examine witnesses. On a finding that
an offense has been committed, the Mayor may enter an order determining that
the offending dog or cat is a restricted pet for such period of time as shall
be deemed necessary to protect the safety of persons and property within the
village. Should the Mayor enter an order indefinitely restricting an animal,
the owner or harborer may thereafter, upon application and for good cause
shown, request the Mayor to modify the indefinite restriction.
('80 Code, § 90.04) (Ord. 20-78, passed 10-30-78; Am. Ord. 32-78, passed 12-18-
78; Am. Ord. 16-95, passed 9-25-95)
§ 91.05 RESTRAINT OF RESTRICTED DOG OR CAT.
   It shall be unlawful for any person owning or harboring a restricted dog or
cat to permit such a dog or cat to be outside of any enclosure at any time
except when that dog or cat is restrained by a leash.
('80 Code, § 90.05) (Ord. 20-78, passed 10-30-78)
Penalty, see § 91.99
§ 91.06 VOIDING OF ANIMAL FECAL MATTER.
   It shall be unlawful for an owner or harborer of any animal to fail to pick
up and properly dispose of any fecal matter left by his or her animal on any
private or public property other than the property of the owner or harborer in
charge of such animal.
(Ord. 04-15, passed 8-24-15)
§ 91.07 RESTRAINT OF UNRESTRICTED DOG.
   It shall be unlawful for an owner or harborer of more than two dogs to allow
any of the dogs in his or her custody to be unrestrained by a leash when on any
public or private property other than the property of the owner or harborer in
charge of the dogs. This restriction shall not apply to special events approved
by the City Manager. Two or fewer dogs may be unrestrained by an owner or
harborer, subject to all other provisions of this section.
(Ord. 07-17, passed 8-28-17)
   HORSES AND BRIDLE TRAILS
§ 91.10 LICENSE.
   (A)   Every person who rides a horse or pony on trails provided for
horseback riding in the village, or on property within the limits of the
village, shall register his or her name with the City Manager, cause his or her
signature to be attached to an agreement to abide by the rules and regulations
for horseback and pony riders, and to accept a license to be issued to him or
her. The signature and issuance of a license shall be a condition precedent to
a person riding a horse or pony on such trails, or on properties within the
limits of the village. A parent of a rider not of legal age shall make
application for the minor and sign the rules and regulations on the minor's
behalf.
   (B)   The bridle trail license year runs from June 1 to May 31 of each year.
('80 Code, § 90.10) (Ord. 32-71, passed 11-29-71; Am. Ord. 29-76, passed 10-25-
76; Am. Ord. 11-78, passed 4-24-78; Am. Ord. 08-21, passed 4-19-21) Penalty,
see §
91.99 (B)
§ 91.11 RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR HORSEBACK AND PONY RIDERS.
   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to prepare and maintain
rules and regulations related to the use of the public and private trails of
Indian Hill provided for horseback riding by licensees. Violations of these
rules and regulations shall be subject to the penalty provisions set forth in §
91.99. The City Manager is further authorized to amend said rules and
regulations, as may be necessary.
('80 Code, § 90.11) (Ord. 32-71, passed 11-29-71; Am. Ord. 08-21, passed 4-19-
21) Penalty, see §
91.99
§ 91.12 EXCEPTIONS.
   Excepted from the provisions of this chapter are the following persons.
   (A)   A rider riding on property owned or leased by him or her, or on
property on which he or she has been given specific written permission to ride,
and this written permission is on file in the City Manager's office.
   (B)   A member of a riding club when riding on the land owned or leased by
the riding club.
('80 Code, § 90.12) (Ord. 32-71, passed 11-29-71; Am. Ord. 2-75, passed 1-27-
75; Am. Ord. 29-76, passed 10-25-76; Am. Ord. 08-21, passed 4-19-21)
§ 91.13 FEES.
   (A)   Each resident of the village procuring a license hereunder shall pay
the sum of $100 beginning June 1, 2021 and $125 beginning June 1, 2022 for each
license or renewal thereof, however, a family fee shall be available at $175
beginning June 1, 2021 and $200 beginning June 1, 2022 to cover the first two
members and $20 beginning June 1, 2021 and $25 beginning June 1, 2022 for each
additional member of the family having need for a license under the terms
hereof. Any resident procuring a license hereunder after December 1 shall pay
half of these amounts, as appropriate, and the license so procured shall be
issued to expire on the following May 31.
   (B)   Each non-resident of the village procuring a license hereunder shall
pay the sum of $125 beginning June 1, 2021 and $150 beginning June 1, 2022 per
year for each license or renewal hereof; however, a family fee shall be
available at $225 beginning June 1, 2021 and $250 beginning June 1, 2022 to
cover the first two members and $25 beginning June 1, 2021 and $30 beginning on
June 1, 2022 for each additional member of the family having need for a license
under the terms hereof. Any non-resident procuring a license hereunder after
December 1 shall pay half of these amounts, as appropriate, and the license so
procured shall be issued to expire on the following May 31.
   (C)   All non-residents of the village who were not current bridle trail
members prior to April 24, 2000, shall, upon paying the membership fees
specified under division (B) above, also be responsible for paying a one-time
initiation fee in the amount of $175 per non-resident member beginning June 1,
2021 and $200 beginning June 1, 2022.
   (D)   Holders of bridle trail licenses may purchase daily passes for guests
to ride in the village with a licensed rider from the following sources: The
Village of Indian Hill Administrative Offices during normal business hours; The
Indian Hill Rangers' front desk after normal business hours; and, any private
stable or riding association which has entered into an agreement with the
village to serve as an agent for the collection of bridle trail fees. Guest
licenses may be purchased for $15 per day for each resident guest and $25 per
day for each non-resident guest.
('80 Code, § 90.13) (Ord. 32-71, passed 11-29-71; Am. Ord. 29-76, passed 10-25-
76; Am. Ord. 11-78, passed 4-24-78; Am. Ord. 4-81, passed 3-30-81; Am. Ord. 7-
89, passed 2-27-89; Am. Ord. 06-00, passed 4-24-00; Am. Ord. 14-02, passed 6-
17-02; Am. Ord. 08-21, passed 4-19-21)
§ 91.14 MAINTENANCE FUND.
   (A)   License fees collected hereunder shall constitute a fund to be
expended by the City Manager for the establishment, maintenance, and repair of
bridle trails and adjuncts thereto, and which shall not be used for any other
purpose without further action of the Council.
   (B)   In the event that the funds in the maintenance fund created by this
section are inadequate in any year to provide for the maintenance service which
is, in the judgement of the City Manager, necessary to the proper maintenance
of the bridle trails of the village, the Comptroller is hereby authorized, upon
exhaustion of the funds in the maintenance fund, to make such transfers from
the general fund to the maintenance fund as are necessary to provide the
maintenance service; provided, that the funds so transferred shall not exceed
the funds which the City Manager is authorized by law to expend without
authorization by the Council.
('80 Code, § 90.14) (Ord. 32-71, passed 11-29-71; Am. Ord. 29-76, passed 10-25-
76)
§ 91.15 MONITORS ON BRIDLE TRAILS.
   (A)   The Mayor may appoint bridle trail monitors in such numbers as he or
she may deem appropriate from time to time, whose duties shall be to request
identification of riders on horseback bridle trails of the village for the
purpose of learning whether the riders are properly licensed.
   (B)   The enforcement duties of the bridle trail monitors shall be limited
to reporting riders without licenses to the Indian Hill Rangers for issuance of
citations, and reporting any other violation of law they observe along the
bridle trails of the village.
   (C)   The monitors shall be 21 years of age or more. The City Manager shall
provide appropriate badges or other insignia to identify the persons serving as
monitors.
('80 Code, § 90.15) (Ord. 23-74, passed 11-25-74; Am. Ord. 08-21, passed 4-19-
21)
§ 91.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any owner or harborer found in violation of §
91.01, §
91.05 or §
91.07 shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. For any subsequent violation
within a 12-month period, said owner or harborer shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
('80 Code, § 90.99 (A)) (Ord. 18-85, passed 11-18-85; Am. Ord. 07-17, passed 8-
28-17)
   (B)   Violation of §
91.06.
      (1)   Any owner or harborer found in violation of §
91.06 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and upon conviction
shall be subject to a fine or penalty of not more than $250.
      (2)   Any owner or harborer found in violation of §
91.06 for the second time within a 30 day period shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine
or penalty of not more than $500 for each offense.
   (C)   Any person who has not registered his name and procured a license as
provided in §
91.10 of this chapter, and who rides on the riding trails or on property within
the limits of the village, and who is not a person who is excepted from these
provisions as provided in §
91.12, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of not more than
$100 for each offense of which he is found guilty, or
      (1)   To the revocation of his license; or
      (2)   Both, within the discretion of the judicial officer hearing the
matter.
('80 Code, § 90.99 (B)) (Ord. 7-89, passed 2-27-89; Am. Ord. 06-00, passed 4-
24-00; Am. Ord. 04-15, passed 8-24-15)
CHAPTER 92: FIRE PREVENTION
Section
   
92.01   Adoption by reference
   
92.02   Enforcement by City Manager
   
92.03   Chief of Fire Department; Corporation Counsel
   
92.04   Powers and duties of the City Manager
   
92.05   Open burning regulations
 
   
92.99   Penalty
§ 92.01 ADOPTION BY REFERENCE.
   The Ohio Fire Code, as subsequently revised or amended, is incorporated
herein by reference as fully as if set out at length and verbatim. Copies of
the Ohio Fire Code are available for public inspection at the village
administration building.
('80 Code, § 93.01) (Ord. 9-69, passed 3-27-69; Am. Ord. 3-72, passed 1-24-72;
Am. Ord. 18-80, passed 10-28-80; Am. Ord. 17-96, passed 11-18-96; Am. Ord. 06-
15, passed 10-19-15)
§ 92.02 ENFORCEMENT BY CITY MANAGER.
   (A)   The fire prevention code shall be enforced by the City Manager.
   (B)    During such periods as the Madeira and Indian Hill Joint Fire
District is in operation and is under contract with the village to provide fire
protection services to the village, the City Manager shall delegate enforcement
of the code to the Joint Fire District, acting by and through the Chief,
employees and appointees of the Joint Fire District, and such persons shall
serve as inspectors.
   (C)   During such periods as the Madeira and Indian Hill Joint Fire District
is not in operation, the City Manager may detail members of his staff to serve
as inspectors as he may see fit, and as shall from time to time be necessary.
('80 Code, § 93.02) (Ord. 9-69, passed 3-27-69; Am. Ord. 10-88, passed 6-20-88)
§ 92.03 CHIEF OF FIRE DEPARTMENT; CORPORATION COUNSEL.
   (A)   Whenever the terms CHIEF OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT or CORPORATION COUNSEL
are used in the code they shall be held to mean the Manager and the Solicitor
of the village, respectively.
   (B)   Provisions of the fire prevention code relating to uses prohibited by
the zoning laws or other ordinances of the village shall not be construed as
permitting such uses.
('80 Code, § 93.03) (Ord. 9-69, passed 3-27-69)
§ 92.04 POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE CITY MANAGER.
   (A)   The City Manager shall have the power to modify any of the provisions
of the code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly
authorized agent, when there are substantial practical difficulties in the way
of carrying out the strict letter of the code, provided that the intent of the
code is preserved, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The
particulars of the modification when granted or allowed shall be entered upon
the records of the City Manager and a signed copy furnished the applicant.
There shall be no administrative appeal from the decision of the City Manager.
   (B)   The Manager shall determine and specify, after hearing, any new
materials, processes, or occupancies that shall require permits, in addition to
those now enumerated in the code. The City Manager shall post a list of such
new materials, processes, and occupancies in a conspicuous place in his office.
('80 Code, § 93.04) (Ord. 9-69, passed 3-27-69)
§ 92.05 OPEN BURNING REGULATIONS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this section the following words and phrases shall
have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.
      GARBAGE. Any matter resulting from the handling, processing, preparation,
cooking, and consumption of food or food products.
      LANDSCAPE WASTE. Any vegetable or plant matter except garbage, including
trees, tree trimmings, branches, stumps, brush, weeds, leaves, grass,
shrubbery, yard trimmings, and crop residues.
      OPEN BURNING. The burning of any materials wherein air contaminants
resulting from combustion are emitted directly into the air without passing
through a stack or chimney from an enclosed chamber. For purposes of this
definition, an enclosed chamber is one which has only those ducts, stacks, or
chimneys necessary to provide combustion air and to permit the escape of
exhaust gas. The burning of any materials in metal cans, barrels, containers,
wire baskets, or any homemade device is open burning. The burning of materials
in incinerators is open burning. The burning of materials in incinerators is
governed by Ohio Environmental Protection Agency Regulation EP-11-09.
   (B)   No person shall cause or allow open burning within the village, except
as provided in §
92.05(C) and (E).
   (C)   (1)   Open burning shall be allowed for the following purposes without
notification to or permission from the Fire Chief and authorization from the
Ohio Division of Forestry, Hamilton County Environmental Services, and the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency:
         (a)   Heating tar, welding, acetylene torches, highway safety flares,
heating for warmth of outdoor workers, smudge pots, and similar occupational
needs.
         (b)   Bonfires, campfires and outdoor fireplace equipment, whether for
cooking food for human consumption, pleasure, religious, ceremonial, warmth,
recreational or similar purposes.
      (2)   Fires allowed by division (C) shall not be used to burn garbage,
landscape waste, or any other waste material, and shall be a total fuel area of
three feet (914 mm) or less in diameter and two feet (610 mm) or less in height
of minimum size sufficient for their intended purpose and shall not be
conducted within 25 feet (7620 mm) of a structure or combustible material. The
fuel used shall be clean seasoned firewood, natural gas or equivalent, or any
clean burning fuel with emissions that are equivalent to or lower than those
created from the burning of seasoned firewood.
      (3)   Recreational fires conducted in gas-fired recreational pits and
portable outdoor fireplaces shall be used in accordance with the manufacturer's
instructions and shall not be operated within 15 feet (3048 mm) of a structure
or combustible material.
      (4)   The Fire Chief may issue a ban on open burning, recreational fires,
or the use of portable outdoor fire places at any time when conditions warrant,
including during times when the state fire marshal has issued a ban as long as
the local ban does not contradict the ban issued by the state fire marshal.
   (D)   (1)   Open burning shall be permitted after first obtaining a permit
from the Fire Chief, and authorization from the Ohio Division of Forestry and
Hamilton County Environmental Services, for the following purposes:
         (a)   Prevention or control of disease or pests.
         (b)   Ceremonial purposes. Ceremonial fires shall be less than five
feet by five feet and shall burn no longer than three hours.
         (c)   Recognized horticultural, silvicultural, range, or wildlife
management purposes.
      (2)   Fires allowed by division (D) shall not be used to burn garbage,
landscape waste, or any other waste material. The fuel used shall be a clean
fuel, that is, a fuel chosen to minimize the generation and emission of air
contaminants such as clean, seasoned firewood or equivalent.
   (E)   Open burning shall be permitted after first receiving a permit from
the Fire Chief and authorization from the Ohio Division of Forestry, Hamilton
County Environmental Services, and the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency for
the purposes set forth in divisions (1) through (3) of this division (E),
provided, however, that the Fire Chief will not issue the permit where such
burning shall be offensive or objectionable due to smoke or odor emissions when
atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous. The
Fire Chief shall order the extinguishment of any open fire, by the permit
holder, or the Fire Department, where the fire adds to or creates a hazardous
or objectionable condition.
      (1)   Disposal of hazardous or toxic materials where the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency determines that there is no practical alternate
method of disposal.
      (2)   Instruction in methods of fire-fighting or for research in the
control of fire.
      (3)   In emergency or other extraordinary circumstances for any purpose
determined to be necessary by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
   (F)   Applications for an open burning permit, as provided for in this
section, shall be made in writing at least ten days prior to the fire being set
and shall be in such form and contain such information as the Fire Chief may
require. Such application shall include authorization for open burning from the
Ohio Division of Forestry and the Hamilton County Environmental Services and
describe the purpose of the burning, the nature and quantity of material to be
burned, the date of the burning, the location of the bum site, and the on-site
fire-extinguishing equipment to be provided.
('80 Code, § 91.10) (Ord. 6-74, passed 2-25-74; Am. Ord. 06-97, passed 4-28-97;
Am. Ord. 06-21, passed 4-19-21) Penalty, see §
92.99
§ 92.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the fire
prevention code, as adopted and enacted into law, or fail to comply therewith,
or that shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or that
shall build in violation of or noncompliance with any detailed statement of
specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate
or permit issued thereunder and from which no appeal has been taken, or that
shall fail to comply with any order that is affirmed, or any order as modified,
upon appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed in the
order severally for each and every violation or noncompliance be fined not less
than $25 nor more than $100. When not otherwise expressly provided, each ten
days that violations, noncompliances, or prohibited conditions continue,
whether before or after the imposition of a penalty therefor under this
chapter, shall constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   The imposition of a penalty under this chapter shall not be held to
prevent the forced removal or elimination of prohibited conditions.
('80 Code, § 93.99)
   (C)   (1)   Whoever causes or allows burning in violation of §
92.05 shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $25 per day of burning plus
the cost of proper disposal of the materials burned. Whoever causes or allows
open burning in a second or subsequent violation of §
92.05 shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $50 per day of burning
plus the cost of proper disposal of the materials burned.
      (2)   The cost of proper disposal of the materials burned shall be the
amount it would have cost to dispose of the materials in a manner that is
consistent with the air, water, and solid waste laws, ordinances, and
regulations of the village and the state.
('80 Code, § 91.99(D))
