this chapter, the owner/subdivider agrees to cause the balance to be increased
to such amount as shall be required by the village for such purposes, in the
exercise of its judgment, or shall provide such other guarantee of performance
as may be required by the village.
   (D)   Surety bond.
      (1)   Form. The bond shall be in a form and with a bonding company, and
approved by the City Solicitor.
      (2)   Time limit. The bond shall be payable to the City of the Village of
Indian Hill and be enforceable by same on or beyond a date 36 months from the
date of final plat approval.
      (3)   Release of any bond required herein shall be conditioned on final
approval and acceptance of the improvements by the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.072 TIME LIMIT.
   All performance guarantees shall provide that if required improvements are
not installed within two years of approval of the final plat, the village may
deem the subdivider in default and proceed in accordance with the provisions of
§
154.073.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.073 DEFAULT.
   In the event the City Manager determines, in the sole exercise of his
judgment, that the owner/ subdivider has failed to install the proposed
improvements in accordance with the approved plans and specifications or has
failed to comply with the terms of the guarantees hereinabove set forth, the
village may take the following actions:
   (A)   Cash escrow and letter of credit. The village may advise the owner/
subdivider of failure in writing, giving the same 30 days to cure such default.
If the owner/subdivider fails to cure said default, it is agreed that the
village may, at its option, declare him in default and, upon written
notification to escrowee of such declaration of default, all monies on deposit
pursuant to the escrow agreement shall and may be disbursed by escrowee solely
upon authorization of the City Manager and escrowee shall be released by the
said owner/subdivider as to such payment or payments.
   (B)   Surety bond. The village may inform the bonding company of default by
the owner and request they take necessary actions to complete the required
subdivision improvements.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.074 GUARANTEE AMOUNT.
   The amount of the performance guarantee shall cover all construction costs,
the owner's engineering and platting costs, and the village's engineering and
inspection costs. The guarantees shall be in the following minimum amounts
unless the owner can show that certain of the costs have already been paid.
   (A)   Construction cost:
      (1)   130% of the estimated construction cost approved by the City
Manager; or
      (2)   110% of a binding contract with a contractor qualified for the
proposed work.
   (B)   Owner's engineering and platting cost: at a cost verified by the
engineer and surveyor.
   (C)   Village Engineering and inspection costs: actual costs incurred.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.075 MAINTENANCE GUARANTEE.
   The owner/subdivider shall guarantee public improvements required by this
chapter against defects in materials and workmanship for a period of two years
from the date of acceptance of public improvements by the village. The owner/
subdivider agrees to repair or replace any of said public improvements which,
during said two year period after acceptance, shall become damaged or deficient
due to defective materials or workmanship.
   (A)   Conditions of guarantee. The owner/ subdivider shall establish a cash
escrow account or provide a letter of credit in the amount of 5% of the final
construction costs of the improvements to guarantee cost of replacement of
defective materials within the limits of the improvements. Said escrow account
or letter of credit shall remain in force for the aforesaid two year
maintenance period and shall be for use by the village to effect such repairs
deemed necessary for public safety and which the owner has neglected to repair
for a 48 hour period after notification. Disbursements from the cash escrow
account or pursuant to the letter of credit shall be made solely upon the
direction of the village and shall not be subject to approval or disapproval by
the owner/subdivider or escrowee or the financial institution issuing the
letter of credit or their agents.
   (B)   Return of funds. Within 45 days following the two year maintenance
period, the escrowee or the financial institution issuing the letter of credit
shall pay over to the owner/subdivider, without further demand or notice, any
balance of funds then remaining undisbursed under said letter of credit or
escrow account.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.076 DAMAGE AND NUISANCE GUARANTEE.
   The guarantee of completion of public improvements, to be executed prior to
recording of a final plat of subdivision, shall also provide for repair of
damages and abatement of nuisances with respect to existing and subsequently
installed landscaping, streets, lighting, water and sanitary sewerage
facilities, culverts, catch basins and/or storm sewers. The damage and nuisance
guarantee herein referred to shall be in the total of 5% of the construction
cost of the new public improvements and shall be provided by cash escrow
agreement, letter of credit or surety bond as provided in §
154.070 through
154.078 upon commencement of land development.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.077 CONSTRUCTION CONTROL.
   (A)   Time of construction of improvements. All public and private
improvements required pursuant to this chapter shall be installed after
approval of the final plat. No work shall start prior to said approval.
   (B)   Time of construction of buildings. No building permits shall be issued
for the construction of any building or structure unless a final plat has been
approved and recorded and unless all public improvements are provided to serve
the subdivision in the manner and in accordance with the standards set forth in
this chapter, provided, however, that permits may be issued if all grading
operations and drainage improvements are completed and the base and
intermediate layers of bituminous concrete have been placed on the road or
roads to be improved.
   (C)   Use of existing streets. Only those streets designated by the City
Manager during the approval of the final plat may be used for access to the
subdivision by all equipment and trucks engaged in the construction of all
improvements, utility services and buildings.
   (D)   Sequence of construction. All underground utilities, water mains,
sanitary sewers or storm sewers installed in streets or service roads shall be
installed prior to the surfacing of such streets. Service connections to such
underground utilities and sewers shall be extended to the property line of each
lot so as to prevent disturbing the surface improvements in such public ways
when service connections are later made. Where underground utilities are
located in the parkway adjacent to the paved roadway, service connections to
properties across such roads shall only be made by drilling under the pavement
in such a way that the surfacing is not disturbed or weakened.
   (E)   Maintenance during construction. The owner/subdivider shall clean and
maintain all public ways, sewers and drains free from snow, mud, debris and
trash or other extraneous material prior to acceptance of the street by the
village and at such other times during construction as the City Manager or
Village Engineer may deem necessary in accordance with Section 7.7.10 [sic] of
the Village Code.
   (F)   (1)   Erosion, sedimentation measures and maintenance requirements
during construction. Pursuant to Chapter 153, sediment basins, diversions,
sediment barriers, and other measures intended to trap sediment on-site shall
be constructed as a first step in grading and be made functional before land
disturbance takes place.
      (2)   Temporary stabilization of denuded areas, soil stock piles and all
other requirements of the approved Erosion and Sedimentation Plan shall be in
accordance with the design standards of the Hamilton County Soil and Water
Conservation District.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.078 INSPECTION OF IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   General. Unless otherwise specifically provided, inspection of the
construction of the improvements shall be by the village and paid for by the
subdivider.
   (B)   (1)   Inspection required. All required land improvements to be
installed under the provisions of this chapter shall be inspected at the
subdivider's expense. The subdivider's licensed engineer, as agent for the
subdivider, shall provide an inspector on the job during the process of
construction. When the work has been completed, the subdivider's engineer shall
certify that the improvements comply in all respects with the approved plans
and specifications and with the requirements of this chapter. All work shall be
at all times subject to inspection by the City Manager, the Village Engineer,
other village officials, and their representatives.
      (2)   In the event the village elects to provide inspection of
subdivision construction, the cost of the village inspector shall be determined
in accordance with the current subdivision fee schedule. One-half of the cost
of inspection shall be paid at the time of execution of the final subdivision
plat. The remaining one-half of the inspection cost is to be paid prior to the
final release from the subdivider's guarantee of improvement completion. In the
event the actual cost of engineering services to the village shall exceed the
amounts computed under the subdivision fee schedule, such excess shall be paid
by the subdivider to the village upon final inspection for acceptance and
release of subdivider's completion guarantee.
   (C)   Notification. Before starting the construction of any improvements,
the subdivider shall ascertain from the City Manager what inspections are
required and the amount of notification desired in each case. In no event shall
notice to the Village Engineer be less than 48 hours prior to a desired
inspection.
   (D)   Subdivider's responsibility. Regardless of contracts, agreements or
inspections performed, final responsibility for the installation of all
improvements in accordance with the applicable standards rests with the
subdivider.
   (E)   Time limit on construction of public improvements. All improvements
required under the provisions of this chapter shall be completed within two
years of approval of a final plat or the subdivider shall be considered in
default under the provisions of §
154.073.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
ACCEPTANCE OF PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS; RELEASE OF PERFORMANCE SURETY
§ 154.085 ACCEPTANCE OF PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS.
   If any plat of subdivision contains public streets or easements which are
dedicated thereon as such, whether located within the corporate limits of the
village or in part outside thereof, or contains existing streets located
outside of the corporate limits, approval of the final plat by the Planning
Commission, approval of payouts under the terms of a guarantee of improvement,
or subsequent annexation of the property to the village shall not constitute an
acceptance by the village of such streets or easements, nor of the public
improvements constructed or installed thereon or therein, irrespective of any
act by any officer, agent or employee of the village with respect to such
streets or improvements. The acceptance of all public improvements shall be
made only by the adoption of an ordinance by the Village Council after there
has been filed with the Council a certification by the City Manager stating
that all, or individual, public improvements required to be constructed or
installed have been fully, or individually, completed, and that the
construction or installation has been approved by him.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.086 SUBMISSION OF "AS BUILT" DRAWINGS.
   After completion of all public improvements and prior to final acceptance of
said improvements, the subdivider shall make or cause to be made "as built"
drawings showing the actual location of all improvements. The plan shall be in
black ink on mylar or materials of equal permanence and durability and shall
bear the seal and signature of the subdivider's engineer. The plans consisting
of the original drawings and three sets of blue line prints shall be submitted
to the village for permanent record. Presentation of the plans to the village
shall be a condition of final acceptance of the subdivision improvements.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.087 RELEASE OF PERFORMANCE SURETY.
   No street or roadway shall be accepted by the village for dedication until
75% of all lots in the subdivision in which said street is located shall have
been fully improved with buildings authorized thereon and a certificate of
occupancy has been issued, and surface course of a street or thoroughfare,
shall be collectively considered as a single, or individual improvement and
such construction shall constitute release of the applicable portion of the
performance surety. No street or roadway shall be accepted by the village
during the months of November, December, January, February, March and April
unless otherwise determined by the City Manager.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
SUBDIVISION STANDARDS
§ 154.095 GENERAL.
   All subdivisions in the village shall comply with the minimum standards set
forth in this chapter, the zoning code and all other applicable regulations of
the village. All land improvements proposed in a subdivision, including
building areas of lots, streets, storm drainage, public utilities, sewers, site
grading, and the like shall be constructed within the clearable land area
calculated pursuant to §
154.110 through
154.116 and the appendix to this chapter.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.096 LOT STANDARDS.
   (A)   Lot dimensions; area and setbacks. Lot dimensions, area, and set backs
shall comply with the requirements of the zoning code of the village, as
amended from time to time, for the zoning district in which the property is
situated. Lots shall not block any street extensions which have been set forth
on the official (street) map of the village.
   (B)   Lot abutment.
      (1)   Every lot of a subdivision shall abut on a publicly-dedicated
street or a private street, provided, however, that the Planning Commission may
approve a subdivision, the lots of which do not abut on a publicly-dedicated
street or a private street ("rear lots") if:
         (a)   The rear lot or lots abut on a lot, which in turn abuts on:
            1.   An existing public street; or
            2.   A private street which complies with §
154.097 (B) and (E), or an existing private street which is determined by the
Planning Commission to be of such construction and width and has such other
characteristics as satisfy the purposes of this section;
         (b)   The rear lot or lots are served by an unobstructed easement not
less than 40 feet in width which connects such rear lot or lots with the
existing public or private street described in division (B)(1) above; and
         (c)   The rear lots permit more efficient lotting and avoid the
construction of a street in an environmentally sensitive area.
      (2)   Rear lots shall not be approved if the Planning Commission shall
determine that their primary purpose is to avoid the construction of a public
street, that such lots would create a safety hazard, or that such lots would be
inconsistent with the village's adopted land use objectives and policies.
   (C)   Double-frontage lots. Double-frontage lots and reversed-frontage lots
are not permitted, except in such instances where such a lot arrangement will
avoid the construction of lots that face on principal or secondary streets.
   (D)   Side lot lines. Side lot lines shall be approximately at right angles
or radial to the right-of-way line of the street on which the lot faces.
   (E)   Corner lots. In order to permit conformance with the front yard depth
on the side street required by the zoning ordinance, a corner lot shall be
platted 50 feet wider than the minimum frontage required for interior lots by
the applicable zoning district.
   (F)   Remnant parcels. No remnants of property shall be left which do not
conform to all lot requirements, unless such remnant parcels are accepted by
the village for public purposes.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.097 STREETS.
   (A)   General. All improvements required by this section shall be
constructed in accordance with the following general standards.
      (1)   Convenient access to all property within a subdivision shall be
afforded by either a dedicated public street or a private street. Private
streets will be considered by the Planning Commission depending on site
suitability, provided that a binding agreement contained in the plat or other
recorded or registered document shall assure the continued existence and
maintenance of said street or access.
      (2)   Proposed streets which are obviously in alignment or continuation
of existing streets already named shall bear the name of such existing streets
whether in the village or in unincorporated areas. In no case shall the names
for proposed streets duplicate existing street names, irrespective of the use
of a suffix (such as street, road, boulevard, drive, place or court, and the
like) or an abbreviation thereof. Street names shall be approved by the
Planning Commission which shall keep a list of all street names in the village.
      (3)   No permanent building or structure or permanent improvement of any
type shall be erected within the extension of street rights-of-way indicated on
the official [street] map of the village.
      (4)   As far as practicable, all proposed streets shall be continuous and
in alignment with existing, planned or platted streets with which they are to
connect.
      (5)   Proposed rights-of-way for streets shall be extended to the
boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography or
other physical conditions, or unless, in the opinion of the Commission, such
extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of
the subdivision with the existing layout, or the most advantageous future
development, of adjacent tracts. Cul-de-sac streets of reasonable length will
be approved where necessitated by topography or where, in the opinion of the
Commission, they are appropriate for the type of development contemplated.
      (6)   Proposed streets shall follow contour lines wherever practicable.
      (7)   Proposed streets shall intersect one another as nearly at right
angles as topography and other limiting factors of good design permits and
where sight distance is sufficient for traffic safety.
      (8)   Whenever there exits adjacent to the tract to be subdivided a
dedicated or platted and recorded half-width street or service drive, the other
half width of such street or service drive shall be platted.
      (9)   In the rear of lots fronting on principal village streets, where
practicable, provision shall be made for service drives when required by the
Commission.
   (B)   Right-of-way and pavement widths.
      (1)   The minimum width of a right-of-way of and minimum pavement widths
of public streets and service drives shall be as follows:
Public            Right-of-Way      Pavement

      (2)   When any subdivision or part of a subdivision is adjacent to only
one side of an existing right-of-way, which is less than the required width,
the subdivider shall dedicate additional right-of-way to meet the requirement
in accordance with this regulation. Half -streets in new subdivisions are not
permitted. A planted or landscaped area shall be provided in the center of the
turning circle of cul-de-sacs.
   (C)   Block standards. Block lengths and widths shall be coordinated with
the development of the land and shall be designed in a manner that will allow
proper traffic flow, including fire fighting equipment and pedestrian use, and
pedestrian accessways within the blocks to schools, parks or other destinations
as may be required by the Planning Commission. In addition, blocks shall be
designed in conformance with the following requirements:
      (1)   Blocks shall be of sufficient width to provide for two tiers of
lots of appropriate length.
      (2)   The lengths of blocks shall be such as, in the opinion of the
Commission, are appropriate for the locality and the type of development
contemplated.
      (3)   The number of intersecting streets along principal village streets
shall be held to a minimum.
   (D)   Public street design standards.
      (1)   (a)   Street grades and curves for public streets shall conform to
the following standards:
      Minimum   Minimum Radii
   Maximum   Grade at   of Curvature
Type   Grade   Gutter   on Center Line

Street
         (b)   All changes in street grades shall be 41.55 connected by
vertical curves of a minimum length equal to 15 times the algebraic dif-ference
in the rate of grade, for principal village streets, and one-half of this
minimum for all other streets. A tangent at least 100 feet in length shall be
provided between reversed curves. In areas of sensitive natural resources, the
horizontal alignment of minor streets may be varied by the Planning Commission
to avoid the destruction of mature trees or other important natural features.
      (2)   Intersections shall conform to the following standards:
         (a)   At street intersections property line corners shall be rounded
by an arc, the minimum radius of which shall be ten feet.
         (b)   Street curb or street pavement intersections shall be rounded by
radii of at least 25 feet.
         (c)   The above minimum radii shall be increased when the smallest
angle of intersection is less than 60 degrees, or in any case where the
Commission considers an increase necessary.
      (3)   Street pavement design and all street appurtenances shall comply
with §
154.037 (B)(7) of the Village of Indian Hill Standard Construction Drawings
and/or the latest edition of the State of Ohio Department of Transportation
Construction and Material Specifications.
   (E)   Special private street standards. If private minor streets are
approved by the Planning Commission, the street shall comply with the
applicable design standards in division (D) of this section and any exceptions
shown in the village standard construction drawings.
   (F)   Trees and plants. Trees and plants shall be provided in accordance
with the requirements of §
154.150 through
154.154.
   (G)   Signs. Street name signs will be erected by the village at all
intersections created by the development. Customized or specially designed
street signs may be erected by the developer in lieu of village signs, provided
that the sign face material and design are in accordance with current village
standards and are approved by the village. Ornamental entranceway structures,
as permitted by §
155.08 of the zoning code, may be erected at street entrances. Such
entranceways, however, shall not include the name of the subdivision.
   (H)   Special soil regulations for streets.
      (1)   Organic soils. If during the construction of proposed streets or
roads in a subdivision organic soils are discovered, all organic materials
shall be removed to solid subsoil in the area of the proposed street or road
and replaced with fill materials that allow movement of ground water in its
natural state through the fill and provides the required structural support for
the roadway. All such streets shall be elevated above the expected high water
in the area, as determined by the soils summary pursuant to §
154.036 (B)(6), so as to provide a minimum of two feet between the pavement
surface and the water. In no instance shall the pavement base course be
constructed within six inches of the expected high water.
      (2)   Wet soils. If the construction of proposed streets and roads in a
subdivision is to go through wet soils, positive ground water control must be
achieved. The surface of all roads shall be constructed at an elevation so as
to provide a minimum of two feet between the pavement surface and expected high
ground water or free water surface. In no instance shall the pavement base
course be constructed within six inches of expected high water, as determined
by a report certified by the subdivider's engineer. All designs shall insure
that natural drainage is maintained. In no instance shall movement of ground
water be impeded so as to promote build-up of hydrostatic pressure on one side
or the other of a proposed roadway.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.098 STORM DRAINAGE.
   (A)   All storm drainage and management of storm water runoff shall conform
to the requirements described in the Village of Indian Hill Storm Water
Drainage Manual, latest version.
   (B)   Construction activities disturbing 5,000 square feet or more of total
land shall be required to implement post-construction storm water management
facilities or best management practices (BMPs). Construction activities
disturbing one or more acres of total land, or will disturb less than one acre
of land but are part of a larger common plan of development or sale that will
ultimately disturb one or more acres of land, shall obtain coverage through the
OEPA NPDES Construction General Permit, latest version. The threshold acreage
includes the entire area disturbed in the larger common plan of development or
sale. Post-construction storm water management facilities or BMPs shall comply
with the post-construction storm water management requirements prescribed in
the Ohio EPA General Storm Water Permit for Construction Activities.
   (C)   Post-construction storm water management facilities and BMPs that have
been reviewed and approved by the Village of Indian Hill shall be required to
enter into a maintenance agreement following construction to ensure adequate
long-term operation and maintenance. The Village of Indian Hill shall utilize
its Post-Construction Storm Water Management Facility Maintenance Agreement as
the mechanism for long-term operation and maintenance requirements of post-
construction storm water management facilities or BMPs.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97; Am. Ord. 12-20,
passed 11-23-20)
§ 154.099 PUBLIC UTILITIES.
   (A)   Telephone, electric, gas, water, and cable T.V. service lines. All
telephone, electric, gas, water and cable service lines shall be placed
underground throughout the entire subdivision area. All conduits or cables
shall be placed within easements or dedicated public ways in a manner which
will not conflict with other underground service. All such telephone, electric,
gas, water and cable service lines shall be located and constructed to minimize
or eliminate flood damage. Above-ground structures identified with said
underground service facilities shall be located so as not to be unsightly or
hazardous to the public and shall be landscaped.
   (B)   Water service. Installation of water service mains shall conform to
the provisions of Chapter 52 (Water Works).
   (C)   Utility easements. Utility easements of not less than ten feet in
width shall be dedicated where necessary to provide a proper continuity for
such utilities from lot to lot and from block to block. No structures shall be
constructed upon the easements. Additional easements shall be provided for
utilities, drainage an other public services and requirements in order to
provide proper operation and maintenance of said facilities.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.100 PUBLIC SEWAGE TREATMENT AND DISPOSAL SYSTEMS.
   (A)   Where, in the opinion of the Commission and Metropolitan Sewer
District, a public sewer main, is reasonably accessible, the subdivision shall
be provided with a complete sewer system connected with such public sewer main.
The plan for such public sewer system shall be approved by the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency as provided in R.C. § 6111.44.
   (B)   When it is deemed that connection to a public sewer main is not
feasible, a developer shall submit to the City of Indian Hill Board of Health
and the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency a plan pro-posing a private
household sewage system pursuant to §
154.101 of this chapter.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.101 PRIVATE SEWAGE TREATMENT AND DISPOSAL SYSTEMS.
   (A)   General.
      (1)   The Planning Commission may, when it deems necessary for the
health, comfort, safety and general welfare of the present or future population
of the area and necessary to the conservation of water supplies and drainage
sources, prohibit the subdivision of land requiring the use of septic tank and/
or aerobic systems for the disposal of sanitary waste.
      (2)   No lots in a subdivision shall be sold or offered for sale, whether
or not such sale involves a transfer of title or deed, until the developer has
received approval of plans for a private system.
   (B)   Submission of proposal. Any subdivider who proposes to create a
subdivision which utilizes private household sewage disposal systems shall
first provide evidence in writing to the City Manager that the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency considers it to be impracticable or unadvisable
to install a central sewage system pursuant to the applicable sections of the
Ohio Revised Code and Ohio Sanitary Code and that individual on-site systems
are permitted.
   (C)   Submission of plan. Upon submission of the information required
pursuant to division (B) above, the subdivider shall submit to the City Board
of Health for its review and approval a plan clearly showing that the
installation of household sewage disposal systems will comply with all
provisions of Chapter 50 (Sewer Regulations) and with the applicable provisions
of the Ohio Sanitary Code. The plans shall show:
      (1)   The total land area to be used;
      (2)   Location and size of all lots;
      (3)   The properties and characteristics of the soils in the subdivision;
      (4)   Depth to normal ground water table and rock strata;
      (5)   Location of all bodies of water, streams, ditches, water lines,
sewers, drain tile, or any other information which may affect the installation
or operation of individual household sewage disposal systems; and
      (6)   Existing and finished grade of all lots.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.102 MONUMENTS.
   Monuments shall be placed in accordance with the specifications and
provisions for boundary surveys in the State of Ohio, R.C. Chapter 4733-37, or
as amended. Each lot in the subdivision shall have permanent monuments set to
enable surveyors to correctly identify resource protection areas.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.103 SITE GRADING.
   (A)   Contour map. When site grading other than roadway excavation is
proposed within a subdivision, a contour map shall be prepared showing the
confines of the area to be graded and the proposed and existing contours within
the area. All site grading must take place within the clearable land area
calculated pursuant to the provisions of §
154.110 through
154.116.
   (B)   Regraded areas.
      (1)   All regraded areas shall be reseeded upon completion of the grading
and topsoil shall be added as the village shall determine to be necessary. All
areas shall be seeded with a class II mixture and fertilizer. The developer
should also give consideration to restoring select areas with natural growths
of wild flowers, ground cover, or similar material.
      (2)   Steep slopes, greater than three to one (3:1) shall be restored by
means of sod or suitable ground cover.
   (C)   Erosion control plan. Prior to starting any site or roadway grading
operations, an erosion control plan, if one is required, prepared in accordance
with the standards set forth in
Chapter 153 of (Soil Erosion and Sediment Control) must be on file and approved
by the village.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
NATURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION STANDARDS
§ 154.110 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the natural resource protection standards ("resource
protection standards") set forth in this subchapter is to control the intensity
of development in relation to the natural capacity of the site so as to
minimize the disruption of natural functions and ecological processes and to
preserve and protect the natural resources and significant and/or unusual
environmental features of the village.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.111 SCOPE OF APPLICATION.
   The resource protection standards set forth in this subchapter shall apply
pursuant to §
154.035 through
154.038 to all improvements and subdivisions of land identified in §
154.004, in addition to the requirements for lot area, height, frontage and
yards set forth in the zoning code.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.112 WAIVER.
   The resource protection standards set forth herein may be waived by the
Planning Commission upon a finding that the parcel or tract in question does
not contain any of the natural resources or features which are the subject of
these regulations.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
§ 154.113 RESOURCE PROTECTION STANDARDS.
   All developments identified in §
154.111 shall comply with the resource protection standards set forth below:

4.   Mature Canopy Forest (16 )   70%
   Natural Resource            Undeveloped
5.   Young Canopy Forest (4 )      40%
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.114 CANOPY FOREST ABUTTING VILLAGE STREETS.
   Any portion of a parcel of land which abuts a principal or secondary village
street listed in §
154.009, and which consists of mature or young canopy forest shall be
designated as a resource protection area in its natural condition along the lot
frontage for a minimum depth of 30 feet. The property owner may clear areas for
driveways and utilities, but in no case shall these areas exceed 20% of the
frontage. Such areas must be included in the calculation made for mature or
young canopy forests pursuant to the appendix to this chapter.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.115 RESOURCE PROTECTION ANALYSIS.
   As part of the application for concept plan approval or for preliminary plat
approval, as the case may be, an applicant shall submit all information
reasonably necessary to identify and verify the existence, if any, of the
natural resource features listed in §
154.113. All plans for development shall clearly identify the location and
total areas of all such features and shall conform to the resource protection
standards set forth in §
154.113. The types and amount of natural resources requiring protection
pursuant to §
154.113 shall be calculated and submitted as part of the concept plan or
preliminary plat applications using the form set forth in the appendix to this
chapter. A resource protection manual (Guide to Applying Natural Resource
Protection Standards to a Proposed Development) may be obtained at the office
of the City Manager.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.116 PRESERVATION OF RESOURCE PROTECTION AREAS.
   (A)   Designation and use. Resource protection areas that are identified
pursuant to §
154.113,
154.114, and
154.115 shall be designated on the final plat of subdivision as such and in no
case shall designated resource protection areas be developed. Land which is
designated as a resource protection area pursuant to this section shall be used
for resource protection and such other purposes as the Planning Commission
shall approve and authorize to be designated on the final plat, subject to such
conditions as the Commission may deem appropriate. Access to land designated
strictly for resource protection shall be restricted in order to ensure such
protection. Except as otherwise provided in this section, no area occupied by
structures, roads, road rights-of-way or parking areas shall be counted as
designated resource protection areas.
   (B)   Methods of preservation. Resource protection areas shall be designated
so their use and enjoyment as natural areas is not obstructed. The form of
ownership of resource protection areas shall be designated on the final plat.
Resource protection areas shall be owned and preserved by either of the
following two methods or a combination thereof:
      (1)   Conveyance of the resource protection areas to the village as
trustee of and under the Green Areas and Recreational Fund pursuant to §
155.08(F) for which the developer may qualify for a credit on the clearable
land area pursuant to the appendix to this chapter, and/or a special exception
to required minimum lot sizes pursuant to §
155.08; or
      (2)   Deed restricted private ownership which shall prohibit in
perpetuity the development and/or subsequent subdivision of the resource
protection areas or their use for purposes other than those specified in §
154.116. The responsibility and standards for all resource protection areas
shall be specified and provision shall be made for guaranteeing such
responsibility.
   (C)   Clearable land area. The acreage of clearable land identified in the
appendix to this chapter may be combined with resource protection areas, minus
the public or private street rights-of-way, for the purpose of calculating the
number of lots permitted on a parcel under the applicable district regulations
pursuant to §
155.07, provided, however, that the combined total acreage of all areas
clearable for development on the parcel shall not exceed the clearable land
area as calculated pursuant to the appendix to this chapter.
   (D)   Procedures required for on-site improvements. Prior to commencing
improvements on a site on which resource protection areas have been designated
pursuant to §
154.113,
154.114, and
154.115, the owner/subdivider shall stake off and install a barrier fence along
the designated resource protection areas. Any owner/subdivider who fails to
comply with this provision prior to commencement of improvements on the site,
or fails to maintain fenced off areas on the site during such improvements,
shall be subject to a fine pursuant to the provisions of §
154.999 for each day on which improvements were performed in violation of this
section. An owner/subdivider found guilty of such a violation, which has also
resulted in the destruction of designated resource protection areas, shall, in
addition, be liable for the costs of restoring such resource protection areas
to their natural condition.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
GREEN AREAS GIFTS AND BRIDLE TRAIL EASEMENTS
§ 154.120 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the green areas gift program is to protect the village's
natural resource areas ranging from flat, open, grassy fields to steeply sloped
forests in a creative manner as to benefit both developers and the residents of
the village. The purpose of the bridle trail easement program is to provide
licensed bridle trail riders the opportunity to safely enjoy safe access
through these natural resource areas.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.121 GENERAL INTENTION.
   Developers are encouraged to make green areas gifts to the village and
designate land to be included in the bridle trail system. Land proposed for a
bridle trail easement should serve as a natural extension to existing green
areas and enable the provision of a ten foot wide easement that will supplement
the existing bridle trail system.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.122 CREDITS.
   Developers who donate land to the village as a green areas gift or designate
land as part of a bridle trail easement may be given a credit to the clearable
land area calculated pursuant to the appendix to this chapter.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.123 ACCEPTANCE REQUIRED.
   Proposed green areas gifts and bridle trail easements must be accepted by
the Planning Commission and Village Council before any credit is granted to the
developer.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
RESTORATION STANDARDS
§ 154.130 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the restoration standards in this section is to ensure that
all designated resource protection areas that are disturbed or destroyed during
construction of improvements are restored in a manner consistent with the
natural resource protection standards set forth in §
154.154.110 through
154.116.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.131 GENERAL INTENTION.
   Restorative measures as set forth in this chapter are intended to concern
only those areas of the subdivision in which resource protection areas are
disturbed or destroyed during construction of public improvements or subsequent
private residential improvements. The developer is encouraged to provide
additional landscaping throughout the subdivision that will complement the
existing features and the developed site pursuant to §
154.150 through
154.154.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.132 REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Whenever it becomes apparent that construction of subdivision
improvements or residential improvements will or has adversely affected a
designated resource protection area, the developer, builder, or property owner
shall be required to submit a site plan indicating the limits of the affected
area and an inventory of the trees located within that affected area.
   (B)   (1)   Forested area. In any area in which forested areas to be
preserved in accordance with the resource protection requirements of §
154.110 through
154.116 are destroyed during the construction of public or private improvements
of the subdivision, such trees that are destroyed shall be replaced on a one-
for-one basis for all trees larger than four inches diameter at breast height
(DBH). Replacement trees shall not be less than three inches in diameter at
breast height.
      (2)   Slopes. Slopes designated as resource protection areas that are
disturbed by grading, excavation, or landfill shall be restored as directed by
the Village Engineer.
      (3)   Kope formation. Kope formation and floodplain areas designated as
resource protection areas that are disturbed by subdivision or residential
improvements shall be restored as directed by the Village Engineer.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97) Penalty, see §
154.999
§ 154.133 SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   All replacement trees shall be located in designated resource
protection areas as directed by the City Manager.
   (B)   All restoration work shall be in accordance with the Ohio Department
of Transportation construction and material specifications.
   (C)   Trees utilized in the landscaping plan shall be selected from the
village-approved listing of land-scape materials on file with the City Manager.
Not less than three species of bushes and three species of trees shall be
utilized in developing a plan for a proposed subdivision.
   (D)   All plantings shall be furnished balled, burlapped, or container
grown.
   (E)   Tree sizes shall not be less than three inches in diameter as measured
at a point 12 inches above natural ground.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97) Penalty, see §
154.999
§ 154.134 FAILURE TO RESTORE DISTURBED AREAS.
   Any owner/subdivider who fails to restore disturbed areas pursuant to the
standards set forth in this section shall be subject to fine pursuant to the
provisions of §
154.999.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97) Penalty, see §
154.999
MAINTENANCE AND USE OF NATURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION AREAS
§ 154.140 PURPOSE.
   Purpose of maintenance in this section is to set forth permitted maintenance
practices and use of privately owned deed restricted resource protection areas.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.141 GENERAL INTENTION.
   Except where requirements are indicated, the provisions in this section
shall be used as a guide for understanding how to maintain and enhance the
designated resource protection areas and exercise control of the area in a
manner consistent with the deed restrictions.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.142 MAINTENANCE OF RESOURCE PROTECTION AREAS.
   (A)   Permitted maintenance. Privately owned resource protection areas
containing mature or young canopy forest, slopes 20% or greater, kope
formation, and/or floodplain should be maintained in the following manner:
      (1)   Eradicate dense invasive ground vegetation which blocks desirable
views or does not provide desirable screening for residential areas;
      (2)   Replace ground vegetation with wild flowers, perennial beds,
evergreens, or desired plantings;
      (3)   Remove or trim dead or diseased trees as directed by the City
Manager.
      (4)   Remove fallen trees from the floor of canopy forest.
   (B)   Accidental removal. Should any mature or young canopy trees be
accidentally removed as a result of maintenance, the owner of the deed
restricted area will be required to replace the trees pursuant to the
requirements of §
154.132(B)(1).
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.143 PERMITTED USE OF RESOURCE PROTECTION AREAS.
   The owner of designated resource protection areas may plant trees or ground
cover as provided in §
154.142(A)(2) and create natural walking paths to enjoy the habitats of birds
and other wildlife. Owners are prohibited from locating any structure,
principal or accessory, within a designated resource protection area. In no
event shall designated resource protection areas be developed except as
provided in this subchapter.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
LANDSCAPING
§ 154.150 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of landscaping standards in this section is to complement the
natural resource protection standards set forth in §
154.110 through
154.116 in order to ensure that the village's rural residential atmosphere is
preserved in a manner consistent with the village's adopted land use objectives
and policies.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.151 GENERAL INTENTION.
   Requirements set forth in this subchapter are minimal in scope and are not
to be interpreted as a restriction on landscaping efforts. Innovative ideas to
naturalize disturbed landscapes that are not required to be protected pursuant
to §
154.110 through
154.116 of this chapter are encouraged as long as they meet the overall
objective of this section and the approval of the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.152 REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   A preliminary and final landscape plan of all proposed landscaping
shall be submitted pursuant to §
154.036(B)(4)(g) and
154.037(B)(9).
   (B)   Location considerations.
      (1)   Open area. In those areas of the right-of-way where no growth
exists, trees and bushes shall be planted in or adjacent to the right-of-way no
closer than 15 feet to the paved edge of the road. At inter-sections, plantings
exceeding three feet at mature height shall not be planted within 50 feet of
the point of intersection of the two street lines. In no case should any
proposed landscaping be located in an area that creates dangerous vehicular
site distances around curves or at intersections.
      (2)   Outside of the right-of-way. In areas outside of the right-of-way
where trees have been destroyed during the development process, replacement
trees may be planted to preserve the natural atmosphere of the village.
   (C)   Other considerations.
      (1)   Bushes and trees utilized in the landscaping plan shall be selected
from the village-approved listing of landscape materials on file with the City
Manager.
      (2)   All plantings, where possible, shall be furnished balled,
burlapped, or container grown.
      (3)   Tree sizes shall not be less than three inches in diameter as
measured at a point 12 inches above natural ground. Bushes shall have a minimum
height of 24 inches above natural ground.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.153 SPECIFICATIONS.
   All landscaping work shall be in accordance with the Ohio Department of
Transportation construction and material specifications.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.154 MAINTENANCE.
   Developer is required to maintain all approved landscaping on all lots
within the subdivision until said lot(s) is sold. After said lot(s) is sold, it
is the property owner's duty to maintain approved landscaping.
(Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 154.170 CITY MANAGER.
   The City Manager shall:
   (A)   Enforce the provisions of this chapter;
   (B)   Conduct a pre-platting conference, if requested by the applicant;
   (C)   Maintain permanent and current records of this chapter, including
amendments thereto;
   (D)   Receive, file and distribute all concept plans, construction plans,
subdivision applications, preliminary and final plats and supporting data;
   (E)   Review and approve, disapprove or approve with conditions,
construction plans;
   (F)   Receive, file and record final plats with the proper authority; and
   (G)   Make all other determinations required by the regulations contained
herein.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.171 PLANNING COMMISSION.
   The Planning Commission shall be entrusted with the following
responsibilities:
   (A)   Refer concept plans to the Green Areas Advisory Committee for its
review and written recommendations;
   (B)   Review concept plans and reports thereon by the City Manager, the
Village Engineer and the Green Areas Advisory Committee and approve,
disapprove, or conditionally approve same;
   (C)   Review all preliminary subdivision plats and reports thereon by the
City Manager and the Village Engineer and approve, disapprove or conditionally
approve same;
   (D)   Review and approve or disapprove all final plats and specifications
for improvements;
   (E)   Grant or deny requests for variations;
   (F)   Initiate and hold public hearings to recommend to the Village Council,
from time to time, such amendments to the subdivision regulations as the
Planning Commission may deem necessary or advisable; and
   (G)   Make all other determinations required of them by the regulations
contained in this chapter.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.172 GREEN AREAS ADVISORY COMMITTEE (GAAC).
   The GAAC shall be entrusted with the following responsibilities:
   (A)   Review any concept plan submitted to it for review by the Planning
Commission and in conjunction therewith conduct a site visit to confirm the
accuracy of resource protection areas as mapped by the applicant; and
   (B)   Submit a written report to the Planning Commission setting forth its
recommendations.
   (C)   Review any proposed green areas gift or bridle trail easement and
forward its written recommendation to the Planning Commission and City Council.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.173 VILLAGE ENGINEER.
   The Village Engineer is hereby vested with the duty and responsibility of
reviewing all engineering plans and specifications concerning required public
improvements and submitting recommendations thereon to the Planning Commission.
He shall also make all other determinations required of him by the regulations
contained in this chapter.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.174 VILLAGE COUNCIL.
   The Village Council, without limitation upon those powers and duties
provided by law, shall have the following powers and responsibilities in regard
to subdivision control:
   (A)   Amend the regulations of this chapter when found necessary and
desirable, as hereinafter provided;
   (B)   Approve or disapprove intended dedications and, by ordinance, declare
public reservations of land;
   (C)   Order the vacation of a street or other public place and fix
compensation therefor; and
   (D)   Make all other determinations required of the Council by the
regulations contained herein.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.175 ENFORCEMENT.
   It shall be the duty of the City Manager to enforce these regulations and to
notify the City Solicitor of any violations or lack of compliance with these
regulations. Upon such notification, the City Solicitor, in addition to the
fines and penalties set forth in §
154.999, and in addition to the remedies otherwise provided by law, is hereby
authorized to institute an appropriate action or proceeding in law or equity to
prevent such violation, or to restrain, correct or abate such violation.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
AMENDMENTS
§ 154.185 INITIATION OF AMENDMENTS.
   The Planning Commission may, from time to time, initiate and conduct public
hearings to consider such changes or additions to the provisions and
regulations in this chapter contained for subdivision control as it may deem
necessary or advisable.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.186 APPROVAL OF AMENDMENTS.
   The Commission shall recommend in writing to the Village Council such
changes or additions to the subdivision regulations upon conclusion of a public
hearing. Such changes or additions shall become effective after their adoption
by the Village Council by the passage of an amendment to this chapter.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89; Am. Ord. 03-97, passed 2-24-97)
§ 154.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm or corporation, who fails to comply with, or
violates, any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor,
and on conviction thereof shall be fined $100 for each such violation. Each day
that any violation continues after notification by the City Manager that such
violation exists shall be considered a separate offense for purposes of
penalties and remedies specified in this section.
   (B)   Any person, firm or corporation, who offers for sale, enters into a
contract for sale, sells, transfers or otherwise disposes of land before all
requirements of this chapter are complied with, or who neglects or refuses to
comply with, or otherwise violates any provision of this chapter, shall be
guilty of a minor misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined $100
for each lot or part of a lot sold, offered for sale, transferred or otherwise
dealt with in violation of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 25-89, passed 9-25-89)
